body:
@adityaatluri can `__constant` also be specified in the rocm backend? Look at the [llvm guide](https://llvm.org/docs/AMDGPUUsage.html#address-spaces) it seems possible:
`Constant | constant | same as global | 64 | 0x0000000000000000 -- | -- | -- | -- | --`
Unfortunately, no. @gstoner how should we solve this?

The fusion rule is mainly done in topi and the current topi schedule injective is not as smart to handle the case. Two possible solutions exist

- break mean into sum(marked as reduction), div(injective)
   - So fusor will know to fuse at sum
- Keep mean, mark it as reduction and manually write the schedule for mean

> break mean into sum(marked as reduction), div(injective)

I tried this, but then the CUDA test complains about injective not being a valid schedule.

> Keep mean, mark it as reduction and manually write the schedule for mean

I'd rather piece together a proper solution than duplicate code :)

schedule_injective so far only handles the sequence that is all injective. 
Schedule reduce is needed for handling reductions.
By break mean into sum and div, i mean do it in nnvm level, instead of the topi level.
@sxjscience , shall I follow https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/l2_normalize   for l2norm implementation?
One alternative is to implement a pass that checks the if statements and merges their conditions into one of the loops when possible.

Loop ordering in general is fairly tricky in this situation because there's many factors at play. Two major things to balance are:
+ memory access stride; generally you want inner loops or those mapped to threads to access adjacent elements so these accesses can be coalesced
+ reuse; if a piece of memory is cached, you want to reuse that piece take advantage of faster cache accesses before moving on

Basically, it depends on how you've set up your cache reads/writes in addition to how you've bound threads to different loop axes. I would try a few different possibilities and experiment as it's pretty difficult to know the precise, best order at a glance :).

For simple ops like ReLU, usually there is little improvement could be made, so we will avoid add them to the external library support for now to reduce the complexity of the project. We will only add the time consuming operator for cases like conv2d.

Close this for now.

OK, I understood.
Thanks for sharing the project's direction.

good to me

This is mainly because the value of integer is indeed too large to fit into int64_t. To make the API simple, we are only passing the value of range int64 integers around the API.

The error raised in cython interface is correct that this is the case which we did not handle well.
in the future, please redirect the general question to https://discuss.tvmlang.org/
Thanks for improving the code during the review process, this is now merged!

Since this is an API improvement, we want to document it clearly.

You need to upgrade your OS/xcode to newer one. Nil will be an undefined behavior and may force to compile code in Metal 1.0. To support union, at least Metal 1.2 is required.
@tqchen you mean change the calculation & document here?https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/d64ff0f19049a34a37d8a17d73bb9b90cfa6d14f/topi/python/topi/nn/pooling.py
So I think we should set it at least to Metal 1.2. Otherwise on some machines, it will cause https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/874
setting 1.2 sounds good

please see if https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1107 can fix the problem.

We still need vulkan SDK to validate the SPIRV tools etc, but we do not need to have vulkan enabled devices to be available

@yzhliu I just mean add documentation about what are the additional options, and how should they correspond translate to the calculation rule. It would be nice to update the topi python implementation as well, as we haven't yet fully transit to c++ (alternatively, redirect the implementation to c++ one)
@tqchen I have added more to c++ function documents. I feel it would be better to redirect python implement to c++ one, other than implement again in python. Any easy way to do so?
yes, checkout topi/tests/python_cpp, which should have already been doing so
